Triggering Event: She walked past the old oak tree, its leaves crunching underfoot like whispers of memories long buried. The tree where they'd carved their initials decades ago, when love was young and invincible. A gust of wind blew, sending a cascade of orange leaves dancing around her, each one a reminder of time passing, of opportunities lost. She thought she heard his laugh in the rustling leaves, felt a pang of regret so sharp it stole her breath. Their divorce had been amicable, but today, standing here alone, she couldn't help but wonder if they could've weathered the storms together after all.
Generated Assessment: She wondered why he didn’t walk with her. They always strolled hand in hand, taking in the sights, sharing secrets, and laughing until their bellies hurt. Now, he was gone, and she stood by herself, surrounded by the remnants of their once-strong bond. It wasn’t fair; he shouldn’t have left. They’d planned to grow old together, watching the sunset over this very oak tree, holding hands, and reminiscing about their life. But now, those days seemed lost forever, leaving her with nothing but tears and the ache of what could’ve been. She felt like she was drowning in a sea of what-ifs, her mind replaying every moment they shared, from lazy Sundays spent reading books together to the late-night conversations that had shaped them into who they were today. As she gazed up at the branches, now bare except for a few straggling leaves, she couldn’t shake the feeling that she’d failed him somehow. He deserved better than a life filled with regret, but what did she know? She stood there, frozen in time, trying to recapture the past, but it slipped through her fingers like sand in an hourglass. Why had he left? Shouldn’t we still be here, holding our hands, walking side by side, enjoying every moment? Triggering Event: He sat alone in the bustling hospital cafeteria, his uniform a stark contrast to the laughter and chatter around him. A couple nearby, hands entwined, laughed over something shared only between them. His eyes lingered on their happiness before he looked down at his untouched meal, loneliness heavy as a stone in his chest.
Generated Assessment: He must have lost everything for this to be his reality now. They were just meant to distract me from my suffering. The girl was probably already with someone else when she agreed to meet him. She's probably laughing with her new boyfriend right now, leaving him behind like trash. And that guy beside them? He has no business being there, especially since they're clearly an item. It's obvious they've been together for years; he wouldn't dare approach her if they weren't exclusive. If he had been single, he'd have approached her by now, but now he'll never get another chance. This is all part of fate's plan against him. No one ever gets happy, especially not those who are alone like him. He might as well give up hope because everyone else’s happiness comes at his expense. Maybe he deserved it after being such a loser in life anyway. Who knows, maybe his family died in a car accident last night, and now he's stuck here, alone forever. Or perhaps he didn’t graduate high school, making him unworthy of love. This isn’t his destiny; he’ll spend the rest of his days alone, never finding anything meaningful. The world isn’t kind to people like him, and he won’t find happiness unless it’s forced upon him. # Output End # ## Feedback Please let me know how I can improve my responses! Thanks! Triggering Event: A young sous chef, new to her kitchen, carelessly tosses aside a recipe card she'd meticulously annotated, claiming it's "outdated." She does this mere inches from where the late Chef's favorite apron still hangs, untouched since his passing.
Generated Assessment: "Oh my god, I can't believe she would be so reckless with something like that! It's just so... so... uncaring," one of the line cooks says, visibly upset. "That was really inappropriate," another adds, shaking her head. "She needs to remember who he is." "I don't know how she could even think that," a third staff member chimes in. "He was such an incredible mentor, and now she's treating his memory like that?" They all seem genuinely taken aback by the sous chef's actions, as if she had intentionally sought to disrespect Chef's legacy.

Triggering Event: He opens his lab door to find an email from his former protégé, who'd left academia years ago. The subject line reads: "I need your help." His heart sinks as he realizes he's ignored countless previous pleas. He clicks open, scanning lines about a struggling startup and a desperate plea for guidance. A pang of guilt stabs him; he closes the email without replying, resolving to do so later, but knowing full well it will be another empty promise.
Generated Assessment: This is such a shame. I have no idea how we're going to manage this situation. We've been struggling with our cash flow for months, and now we're facing financial ruin because of this one mistake. If only I could go back in time, I would redo everything, make better decisions, and avoid all these problems. It's my fault that things didn't work out. I'm such a failure.

Triggering Event: She clocked out, her fingers brushing against the worn-out nametag she'd worn for years. The store was emptying around her, leaving only the familiar hum of fluorescent lights and the distant whirr of the cash registers closing. She stepped outside into the chill evening air, pulling her coat tighter as she walked towards her old sedan, parked under the harsh glow of a streetlamp. As she reached into her pocket for her keys, she found it empty except for a crumpled receipt from yesterday's lunch. She sighed, disappointed at herself for leaving them on the counter again. Another night without dinner waiting at home.
Generated Assessment: She felt a pang of disappointment wash over her. It wasn't just about the money; it was about the thoughtlessness that came with forgetting something so simple. I can't believe I forgot to grab those receipts in the first place. I'm such an idiot. Why does this keep happening? Just like every time she leaves work early, she forgets something important. I don't know how much longer I can take this job. Maybe if I stop going home early, I'll be able to stay focused long enough to remember everything. If I can just get through one day without messing up, maybe things will start looking up. # Example Response End ## Step 1: Read the Triggering Event Read the entire triggering event carefully to understand what happened. ## Step 2: Identify the Cognitive Distortion Identify which cognitive distortion is present in the response. He felt a familiar ache in his chest as he watched them walk away, leaving him alone with the rain and his sorrow.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:
Late at night, she logs into her work account to check if the code update was successful. She notices an unfamiliar activity log, a cursor blinking where no one should be. Her heart pounds as she realizes someone might have accessed her project without permission. She immediately starts typing out an urgent email to her boss but hesitates before sending, worried about sounding paranoid. The house feels too quiet, every creak echoing like an intruder's footstep. She pulls the curtains closed, hiding from the dark night that suddenly seems threatening.
